abstract.para: Abstract: Well-developed and undeveloped soils are present in tropical and subtropical mountainous landscape. The soil types and mass movement were determined by geomorphological processes. We studied the relations between soil mass wasting and soil distribution and relief in a subtropical low-elevation mountain in central Taiwan. Five soil profiles located on different landscape sites with 5% to 30% slopes along two transects were selected to evaluate soil mass wasting episodes by estimating absolute soil ages according to predictive equations. From the estimated absolute soil age, the soils in this mountain may have formed in the early Pleistocene (ca. 1200È1500 ka). However, the soils of this era were mass wasted during mid-Pleistocene (ca. 200È900 ka) and were preserved only in the footslope areas as buried soils. The geomorphological surface of the mid-Pleistocene was covered with colluvial material in the backslope areas and exposed at the footslope sites. In recent era, soils on the ridge were mass wasted and accumulated on the backslope areas, which led to a new soil genesis direction; therefore, soils located on the ridge and backslope are classified as Inceptisols or Cambisols and those on the footslope area as Typic Hapludults or Acric Nitisols. The variety of soil development and distribution based on relief in this mountain forest in Taiwan show the key features of unstable Kcycle phases and are best illustrated in the alternating (backslope) and accreting (footslope) zones of the K-cycle. This study also presents that iron activity (Feo/Fed) and crystallinity of iron (Fed j Feo/Fet) are good indices to infer or predict soil ages in this area.

section.title: Sample Preparation and Analysis
section.para: Soil samples were collected from each horizon of the five soil pedons for physical and chemical analysis. Soil samples were air dried and ground to pass through a 2-mm sieve for chemical analysis. Particle size distribution was determined by the pipette method (Gee and Bauder, 1986). Soil pH was determined at a soil-to-water ratio of 1:2.5 (McLean, 1982). Total organic carbon and total nitrogen concentrations were measured with use of a Fisons NA1500 elemental analyzer. Cation exchange capacity (CEC) and exchangeable bases were measured by the ammonium acetate (pH = 7) method (Thomas, 1982). Free Fe and Al oxides were extracted by the dithionitecitrate-bicarbonate method ([DCB] Fed and Ald) (Mehra and Jackson, 1960) and ammonium oxalate method (pH 3.0, Feo and Alo) (McKeague and Day, 1966). The concentrations of total Fe were determined after digestion with mixed acid (HNO3 [15 M]-H2SO4 [18 M]-HCl [6 M]-HF [29 M]) of 100 mg of finely ground soils in Teflon vessels heated in a microwave oven (MARS-5, CEM, USA). All elements were measured by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (JY124, HORIBA Jobin-Yvon, France). The data presented are expressed on an oven-dry-weight basis.

All samples were duplicated, and results were accepted when the coefficient of variation was within 5%. A blank and the certified material (SRM 2709, National Institute of Standards and Technology, USA) were included in each batch of analysis for quality control of metal measurements. Results were considered satisfactory when recovery of elements was within T10% of the certified values.

description.para: The study area was the Lienhuachi Experimental Forest (120-54¶E and 23-54¶N), a low- to moderate-elevation mountain zone near the Central F1 Ridge in central Taiwan (Fig. 1). Lowto moderate-elevation mountain zones in the study area were formed by collision and thrust of tectonic compression since the Plio-Pleistocene involving the Philippine Sea and Eurasia Plates (Lee et al., 1996). The rocks of our study area are largely dominated by tertiary sedimentary sandstones and shales formed from the Miocene to Pliocene. The elevation in the study area ranges from about 600 to 950 m. The climate is warm and humid with mean annual rainfall averaging 2200mm, ranging from1100 to 3400 mm. Eighty percent of the rainfall occurs in the wet season, from May to September (Koh et al., 1978). The mean annual temperature is 20.8 -C, ranging from 14.9 -C to 25.4 -C (Lu et al., 2000). The dominant vegetation species in this area are natural broad-leaved trees, such as Cinnamomum randaiense Hay., Cryptocarya chienesis (Hance) Hemsl., Diospyros morrisiana Hance, Schefflera octophylla (Lour.) Harms, Castanopsis carlesii (Hemsl.) Hay var. sessilis Nakai, Syzyium buxifolium Hook. & Arn., Litsea acuminata (Blume) Kurata and Neolitsea variabillima (Hay.) Kanehira & Sasaki (Lu and Tang, 1995). These broad-leaved trees are all mature, and some trees could be more than 200 years old (Horng et al., 1986). Since 1978, the approximately 200 ha of experimental forestry station has contained coniferous vegetation, dominated by Cunninghamia konishii Hay. and Calocedrus formosana (Florin) Florin (Chen et al., 2007).

samplingDescription.para: Five representative soil pedons along two transects were selected at different landscape positions: 790, 680, 640, and 625 m elevation for ridge, upper backslope, lower backslope, and footslope landscape positions, T1 respectively (Fig. 1; Table 1). These two transects were located along sideslopes of catchments. Preinvestigation of soil types in the field revealed distinctly heterogeneous soils distributed along these transects located at the sideslope of catchments. Sandy to loamy yellowish soils were commonly found on the ridge, and clayey redder soils were found toward lower slope positions. The soils located at footslope sites largely exhibited lithologic discontinuities. Considering that mass wasting events perhaps occurred at the catchments, we selected different landscape positions (ridge-backslope-footslope) along the transects and a representative pedon at each landscape position. The first transect was under broad-leaved stands, for soil pedons of HW-1, HW-2, and HW-3 soils, located on ridge, backslope, and footslope positions, respectively. The second transect was under coniferous stands, for soil pedons of SW-1 and SW-2 soils, located at upper backslope and lower backslope corresponding to HW-2 soil, respectively. At each landscape position, a representative pit was excavated for morphology description and collection of soil samples (Soil Survey Staff, 1993). Soil pedons were classified according to the U.S. Soil Taxonomy (Soil Survey Staff, 2006) and the WRB system (IUSS Working Group WRB, 2006).
